]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

memory/HDD).]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[PROGRAM]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[The PROGRAM key contains the soft keys related to program functions for
controlling
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[measurements through a
program.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[SYSTEM]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[The SYSTEM key contains system-related functions such as monochromator
adjusting
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[optical alignment, wavelength adjustment, hardware setup, and setting
initialization.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[ADVANCE]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[The ADVANCE key contains functions for setting reference data used to
make
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[comparison judgments on measured data and for logging analysis
data.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[USER]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Frequently used soft keys can be registered on the soft key menu in the
USER
key.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Registering frequently used soft keys in the USER key allows you to
execute frequently
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[used functions in a small number of
steps.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[COPY]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[The COPY key is used to output the measurement screen to the internal
printer or a file.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[When you press the COPY key, the measured waveforms and lists displayed
on the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[screen are output to the internal printer or a
file.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[PRESET]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[The PRESET key clears all internal settings of the AQ6370D except for
the remote
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[interface (ETHERNET, GP-IB, and RS232)
settings.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[UNDO/LOCAL]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[The key's function changes depending on the status of the instrument
when the
UNDO/]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[LOCAL key is pressed. The following table shows the key's
functions.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

Instrument]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

**[Function]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[UNDO action is allowed
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[If the UNDO key is pressed after changing parameter settings,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[changing or deleting data, etc., the previous action (change,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#231f20"}

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[is

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#231f20"}

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[again.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[During remote control by external
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[PC (Remote light is
on)]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#231f20"}

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[1]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:14.0pt;color:#ffffff"}**

**[DATA ENTRY
Section]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[This unit allows you to enter measurement conditions and various other
parameters
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[through the DATA ENTRY section. Three different entry methods can be
used in the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[DATA ENTRY section, the rotary knob, the arrow keys, and the numeric
keypad.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Rotary knob
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[When you press a soft key which has a parameter, the current setting is
displayed in
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[the parameter entry window. Turning the rotary knob raises or lowers
the numeric value
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[shown in the parameter entry window (turn clockwise to increase and
counterclockwise
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[to decrease), and the internal setting changes at the same time.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Note that if the COARSE key is on (lamp on), the numeric value
increase/decrease step
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[will be
larger.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Arrow keys (▲,
▼)]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Pressing the ▲ key has the same effect as turning the rotary knob
clockwise. Likewise,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[pressing the ▼ key has the same effect as turning the rotary knob
counterclockwise.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Holding an arrow key down for 0.5 second or longer activates
auto-repeat.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[If the multi-marker function has been selected, the arrow keys can be
used to scroll the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[marker value display in the data
area.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[COARSE
Key]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[You can raise the digit of settings being entered or the
increase/decrease step for
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[numerical values.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Each time you press this key the setting toggles between ON and OFF.
When ON, the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[lamp lights.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Numeric keypad
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[You can enter numerical values directly into the parameter input window
by pressing
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[keys of the numeric keypad.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[After you have pressed a parameter soft key to display the current
setting in the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[parameter display area, you can press a numeric keypad key to display
the numeric
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[keypad input area including the entered numeric value.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[If the value entered with the numeric keypad is not in the allowed
value range, the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[nearest allowed value will be set.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[μm/ENTER Key and
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}[nm/ENTER
Key]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Enters values input using the numeric keypad or the parameter input
window.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Use one or the other key if entering a parameter value with a
particular unit.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[If a parameter does not have a unit associated with it, you can use
either the μm/ENTER
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[key or the nm/ENTER key.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[BACK SPACE
Key]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Use this key if you make an error when inputting values with the
numeric keypad. The
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[last entered (right-most) character is removed, allowing entry of the
correct character.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[By holding the BACK SPACE key down, you can erase the entire entry in
the numeric
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[keypad input area and make the numeric keypad input area disappear,
returning it to the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[condition preceding numeric keypad input.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Alignment Adjustment \<\<See section 3.6 for the operating
procedure\>\>]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[This function allows adjustment of the optical axis of the instrument's
built-in
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[monochromator (spectroscope).
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The instrument's optical performance is not guaranteed until the
alignment adjustment
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[function has been executed. Failure to perform this adjustment can
result in distortion
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[of measured waveforms. After alignment adjustment has been executed,
wavelength
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[calibration is also subsequently performed automatically. If you are
using the instrument
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[for the first time or using it after it has been severely shaken while
being moved, perform
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[the alignment adjustment procedure after warm-up ends.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Wavelength Calibration \<\<See section 3.7 for the operating
procedure\>\>]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Wavelength calibration can be performed using the internal reference
light source (when
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[the built-in light source specification is -L1) or an external light
source.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Resolution Calibration \<\<See section 3.8 for the operating
procedure\>\>]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Typically the filter response of an optical spectrum analyzer is not
rectangular, and
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[thus the resolution bandwidth differs slightly from the equivalent
noise bandwidth. This
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[difference becomes prominent especially when the wavelength resolution
is high (e.g.,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[0.05 nm or less). The resolution calibration function measures the
equivalent noise
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[bandwidth at each resolution setting and internally sets the resolution
bandwidth to the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[result. The resolution bandwidth appears in parentheses in each of the
resolution soft
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[keys on the resolution screen. The resolution bandwidth accuracy
affects the results of
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[noise measurements and the results of optical power measurements of
wideband light
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[sources. In detail, the resolution bandwidth is used when the following
analysis and
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[computation functions are executed. For details, see pages 3-29 and
3-30.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• WDM
analysis]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• EDFA-NF (optical amp gain, NF
measurement)]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• Power
analysis]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• OSNR and total power of DFB-LD
analysis]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• Total power of FP-LD
analysis]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• Total power of LED
analysis]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• Power spectral density markers, Integrated power
markers]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Auto Measurement \<\<See section 5.1 for the operating
procedure\>\>]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[This function automatically sets the optimal measuring conditions for
the input light and
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[displays the spectrum waveform. This function is useful when the
characteristics of the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[input light are not well known.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The wavelength range of input light that can be auto-measured is
1200--1670 nm.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The measurement conditions that are set automatically are as follows.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[1. Span
(SPAN)]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[2. Center wavelength
(CENTER)]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[3. Reference level (REF
LEVEL)]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[4. Resolution
(RESOLUTION)]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Other measuring conditions (sensitivity, averaging times, number of
sampling points,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[and interval settings) are set to their defaults. The horizontal and
vertical axes of the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[displayed spectrum waveform are zoomed to an appropriate degree.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Single Sweep \<\<See section 5.13 for the operating
procedure\>\>]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[This function executes a single sweep or forcibly stops a sweep
operation.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Smoothing
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**[
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**[\<\<
See section 5.18 for the operating procedure
\>\>]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[This function attenuates the noise in the measured waveform. By using
the Smoothing
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[function, areas on the waveform with a large amount of noise can be
"smoothed out"
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[when
measured.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Power Spectral Density Display \<\<See section 7.4 for the operating
procedure\>\>]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[The power per 1 nm is called the power spectral density.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The level axis of the AQ6370D indicates the absolute power per
wavelength resolution.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[For example, if the resolution is set to 0.1 nm, the power per 0.1 nm
will be
displayed.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Since the optical spectrum of such devices as a gas laser or a laser
diode is narrower
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[than the wavelength resolution of the instrument, the entire power is
accommodated
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[within the band of a resolution. Therefore, the measured power (peak
level) is equal
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[to the total power of the light source. This instrument has been
calibrated to display
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[accurate power under such
conditions.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[On the other hand, natural light or lights such as fluorescent lamps or
LEDs, have,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[in many cases, optical spectrums wider than the wavelength resolution
set for the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[instrument. Therefore, if the instrument measures these lights,
measured power will vary,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[depending on the resolution
setting.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[In order to deal with this issue, the instrument is equipped with the
dBm dBm/nm soft key
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[to allow the level axis displays to switch from the absolute power
(dBm, mW, μW, nW,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[pW) per resolution to power spectral density (dBm/nm, mW/nm, μW/nm,
nW/nm,
pW/]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[nm).
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[In the case of power spectral density displays, a measured value is
converted to power
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[per 1 nm. Therefore, whatever resolution is used for measurement,
certain measured
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[values will always be
available.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[For information on the use of dBm and dBm/nm, see "Power Spectral
Density Display" in
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[section 5.2, "Horizontal/Vertical Axis
Settings."]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The trace computation function can be used to display the power
spectral density in the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[specified bandwidth within the range of 0.1 nm to 10 nm (see section
6.8).]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Note]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Specifications such as level accuracy, measurement level range, and
level linearity of the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[instrument are provided for the absolute power display.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[External Trigger Measurement \<\<See section 5.16 for the operating
procedure\>\>]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[This function performs measurement in synchronization with an external
trigger signal.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The SMPL TRG IN terminal is an input terminal on the TTL level and in
positive/]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[negative logic (which can be set by the \<EXT TRIGGER SETTING\> key).
The SMPL
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[TRG IN terminal is an input terminal for TTL level, positive/negative
logic signals. The
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[measurement points (wavelength/frequency) are incremented each time
edges of input
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[external trigger signals are detected. Thus, sweeping stops when a
number of external
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[trigger signals equaling the specified number of sampling points is
input. (However,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[when the REPEAT sweep is performed, the sweep will be repeated until
the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}**[STOP]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}**[
key is
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[pressed or until trigger signals are no longer input.)
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The delay time (from the time when a trigger signal is detected until
the time when the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[sampling is performed) specific to the instrument is about 20 µs.
Supply the trigger
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[signal at a timing appropriate for the measurement sensitivity. An
optional delay time can
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[be set to this specific delay time. With the DELAY key of the EXT
TRIGGER SETTING
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[key, the 0.0 µs to 1000.0 µs range can be set in units of 0.1 µs.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Note that after the measurement points are set, input trigger signals
during the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[movement to the next measurement point are ignored. The time varies
depending on the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[measurement wavelength band and the number of sampling points (sampling
intervals).
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Since the SMPL TRG IN terminal is pulled up internally, it can be set
to the HIGH level
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[while it is in the open state and to the LOW level while it is in the
GND short state.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Sweep Trigger \<\<See section 5.16 for the operating
procedure\>\>]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[This function performs a single sweep measurement based on an
externally input trigger
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[signal.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The instrument starts a single sweep measurement by allowing sweep
trigger signals on
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[the TTL level and in negative logic to enter the TRGGER IN terminal at
the back of the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[instrument.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The signal logic of the sweep trigger input signals is fixed to
negative logic, which cannot
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[be
changed.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The pulse width of sweep trigger signals must be 5 ms or
more.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The action when entering a sweep trigger is the same as that for the
SWEEP key or
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[SINGLE
key.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The sweep trigger function detects sweep trigger signals by polling in
certain cycles.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Thus, the time after a sweep trigger signal is input until the sweep
starts will fluctuate in
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[the range of 5
ms.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Trigger Output \<\<See section 5.17 for the operating
procedure\>\>]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[This function outputs trigger signals from the trigger output terminal
on the rear panel of
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[the instrument (only during sweeping).
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

wavelength.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[If the Resolution Correction function is turned ON, measured data is
processed by the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[software so that it matches the set
resolution.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[In the following cases, the resolution correction function has no
effect even when turned
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[ON.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• When the set resolution is 0.02
nm]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• When the measured wavelength is 1400 nm or
less]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Turn OFF the resolution correction function when performing measurement
for which the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[level accuracy is

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Trace
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

**[
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

**[\<\<See section 5.12 for the operating
procedure\>\>]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[A trace shows a waveform and measurement conditions. The instrument has
a total of
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[seven independent traces (A through G). Multiple traces can be
displayed at the same
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[time on the waveform screen. In addition, display ON/OFF and mode
settings can be set
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[separately for each
trace.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Traces can be set to the following
modes.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• WRITE mode
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[ ]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Section
6.2]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• FIX mode
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[ ]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[ ]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Section
6.2]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• MAX/MIN HOLD mode
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Section
6.3]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• ROLL AVG mode
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Section
6.4]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• CALCULATE mode
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Section 6.5 to Section
6.9]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The following explains each of the modes.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[WRITE
Mode]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Waveform data are written during
sweeping.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[When a trace is set to WRITE mode, waveform data are written during
measurement,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[and the data are updated. Traces used in measurements are normally set
to WRITE
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[mode. The trace display at the side of the data area changes to
"WRITE."
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[FIX
Mode]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Fixes the data; does not write waveform data.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[When a trace is set to FIX mode, its waveform data are not overwritten
even when
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[measurement is performed. Therefore, the waveform on the screen is not
overwritten. If
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[you want to fix the waveform data of a trace, set the trace to FIX
mode. The trace display
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[at the side of the data area changes to "FIX."
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[2-8]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

**[IM

**[MAX/MIN HOLD Mode (Maximum/Minimum Value Detection Mode)
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Writes the maximum/minimum values of the waveform data for each sweep.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[When a trace is set to MAX/MIN HOLD mode, each time a sweep is
performed, the data
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[at the individual measurement points are compared with prior
measurements, and the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[measurement with the higher level (MAX HOLD) or lower level (MIN HOLD)
is written.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[If you want to measure the maximum or minimum value of a waveform which
changes
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[each time a sweep is performed, set the trace you want to measure to
MAX/MIN HOLD
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[mode and perform REPEAT
sweeping.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The trace display at the side of the data area appears as "MAX HOLD" or
"MIN
HOLD".]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Note that the NOISE MASK soft key setting applies when a waveform is
displayed, and
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[is not affected when a maximum or minimum value is
detected.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[ROLL AVG Mode (Rolling Average
Mode)]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Writes the rolling average values of the waveform data during each
sweep.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[When a trace is set to ROLL AVG mode, each time measurement is
performed the rolling
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[average of the current measurement and past measurements is calculated,
and the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[measurement data are updated. The number of averagings is set in the
range of 2 to
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[100. The trace display at the side of the data area changes to "ROLL
AVG".]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[CALCULATE Mode (Calculation Results
Display)]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Writes the results of calculations performed between data from
different
traces.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[When a trace is set to CALCULATE mode, subtraction between data from
different
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[traces, normalized display, power display per specified bandwidth, or
curve-fit display
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[is performed according to the set CALCULATE mode. Note that CALCULATE
mode
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[can only be set for traces C, F, and G. Also, the available
calculations vary from trace to
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[trace. For more information, see chapter 6.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Normalized Display Function \<\<See section 6.6 for the operating
procedure\>\>]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[This function is one of the trace CALCULATE modes. It normalizes and
displays the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[trace
data.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[With normalized display, normalization is performed and the waveform is
displayed with
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[the waveform peak set to 1 if the sub-scale is linear, or set to 0 dB
if the sub-scale is
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[LOG. One trace can be normalized, either trace A, B, or C. If both
traces selected for
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[calculation are set to "BLANK", then the sub-scale is displayed on the
left side of the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[screen. Otherwise it is displayed on the right side. The calculation
results are displayed
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[in the sub-scale. The trace display at the side of the data area
changes to "NORM
@".]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Curve Fit
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

**[\<\<See section 6.7 for the operating
procedure\>\>]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Makes an approximation of the specified trace waveform. The result is
written to TRACE G.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Calculations are applied to data from the peak to the threshold value.
The threshold
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[value is set in the range of 0 to 99 dB (steps of 1). The trace display
at the side of the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[data area changes to "CRV FIT @."
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Peak Curve Fit \<\<See section 6.7 for the operating
procedure\>\>]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Makes an approximation of the specified trace waveform. The result is
written to TRACE G.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Calculations are applied to mode peaks at or above the threshold value.
The threshold
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[value is set in the range of 0 to 99 dB (steps of 1). The trace display
at the side of the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[data area changes to "PKCVFIT
@".]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Trace
F.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The target trace is a single trace selected from Traces A to
E.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Marker Functions \<\<See section 6.9 for the operating
procedure\>\>]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Marker functions can be used to easily measure wavelength differences
and level
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[differences, and to search for peak wavelengths, peak levels, and
spectrum widths.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[There are markers, line markers, and advanced
markers.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Markers]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[A total of 1025 markers (one moving marker and 1024 fixed markers) are
provided.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Moving markers can be moved to an arbitrary wavelength using the rotary
knob, arrow
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[keys, or numeric key pad. You can also drag the markers with the mouse.
Moving
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[markers can be moved over a waveform to display the marker values
(wavelength
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[and level value) in the data area. If a moving marker is fixed in an
arbitrary position, it
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[changes to a fixed marker.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Fixed markers are markers fixed to a number on which the moving marker
was set. Fixed
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[markers are assigned marker numbers in order starting from 001. You can
enter an
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[arbitrary number using the rotary knob, arrow keys, or numeric key pad.
A number up to
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[1024 can be set. When multiple fixed markers are set, it is possible to
display wavelength
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[differences and level differences between a given marker and adjacent
markers.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Line
Markers]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[There are four line markers----two wavelength line markers and two
level line
markers.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Wavelength line markers show wavelength and wavelength difference, and
level line
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[markers show level values and level difference. Also, you can use line
markers to specify
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[a sweep or analysis range.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Advanced
Markers]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[There are four advanced
markers.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[There are three types of advanced markers: moving marker, power
spectral density
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[marker, and integrated power marker. Advanced markers can be placed on

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

G.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Each marker can be moved to an arbitrary wavelength using the rotary

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

keypad.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[You can also drag the markers with the

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[waveform.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

procedure\>\>]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[This key is used to display a waveform so that parts of the waveform at
or below the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[set value are masked. In addition, when a noise mask value is set, the
waveform is
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[overwritten in real time.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[OFF (-210 dBm), and the range from -100 to 0 dBm (fine: in steps of 1;

procedure\>\>]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[The peak/bottom search function has two search modes: single, in which
a single peak
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[or a single bottom of the measured waveform's level are detected, and
multi, in which
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

displayed at the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

bottom.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[and bottom levels during repeat
sweeping.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Types of Optical
Fibers]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[The instrument can use single mode optical fibers with core diameters
of 5 to 9.5 μm,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[and multimode (GI) optical fibers with core diameters of 50 and 62.5
μm. Functions may
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[be limited or restricted depending on which type of optical fiber is
used. The table below
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[shows which of the typical types of fiber may be used and the
limitations on their use.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Limitations on Wavelength
Resolution]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[The maximum wavelength resolution for the instrument is 0.020 nm, which
is only
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[obtainable when using a single-mode optical fiber with a core diameter
of 9.5
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}[μ]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}[m
or less.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[As shown in Table, the maximum wavelength resolution decreases when
optical fibers
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[with thicker core diameters are
used.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Setting a resolution value finer than those shown in the table below
will simply result in
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[an inaccurate measurement level without improving resolution.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Optical fibers with a thick core diameter are especially useful for
inputting spatial light for
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[measurement, but they have poor resolution.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Choose the best type of optical fiber for your particular application.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Note that the instrument is designed for input through optical fiber
only. It will not work
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[with inputs that do not pass through optical fiber, such as direct
input of a gas laser
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[beam to the optical input connector, or bonding an LED to the optical
input connector. It
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[is important to note that optical spectrum measurements taken through
such inputs are
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[completely
unreliable.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[For spatial light measurements, input the spatial light to the optical
fiber and from the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[optical fiber to the instrument. A variety of adapters are available
for this
purpose.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

***[5.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}***[
Press the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}**[INITIALIZE]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}**[

[ ]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Explanation]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#ffffff"}**

[Typically the filter response of an optical spectrum analyzer is not
rectangular, and
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[thus the resolution bandwidth differs slightly from the equivalent
noise bandwidth. This
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[difference becomes prominent especially when the wavelength resolution
is high (e.g.,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[0.05 nm or less). The resolution calibration function measures the
equivalent noise
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[bandwidth at each resolution setting and internally sets the resolution
bandwidth to the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[result. The resolution bandwidth appears in parentheses in each of the
resolution soft
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[keys on the resolution
screen.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The resolution bandwidth accuracy affects the results of noise
measurements and the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[results of optical power measurements of wideband light sources. In
detail, the resolution
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[bandwidth is used when the following analysis and computation functions
are
executed.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• WDM
analysis]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• EDFA-NF (optical amp gain, NF
measurement)]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• Power
analysis]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Important Points During
Measurement]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:18.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

**[Types of Optical
Fibers]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[The instrument can use single mode optical fibers with core diameters
of 5 to 9.5 μm,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[and multimode (GI) optical fibers with core diameters of 50 and 62.5
μm. Functions may
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[be limited or restricted depending on which type of optical fiber is
used. The table below
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[shows which of the typical types of fiber may be used and the
limitations on their use.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Limitations on Wavelength
Resolution]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[The maximum wavelength resolution for the instrument is 0.020 nm, which
is only
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[obtainable when using a single-mode optical fiber with a core diameter
of 9.5 μm or less.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[As shown in Table, the maximum wavelength resolution decreases when
optical fibers
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[with thicker core diameters are
used.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Setting a resolution value finer than those shown in the table below
will simply result in
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[an inaccurate measurement level without improving resolution.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Optical fibers with a thick core diameter are especially useful for
inputting spatial light for
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[measurement, but they have poor resolution.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Choose the best type of optical fiber for your particular application.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Note that the instrument is designed for input through optical fiber
only. It will not work
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[with inputs that do not pass through optical fiber, such as direct
input of a gas laser
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[beam to the optical input connector, or bonding an LED to the optical
input connector. It
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[is important to note that optical spectrum measurements taken through
such inputs are
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[completely
unreliable.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[For spatial light measurements, input the spatial light to the optical
fiber and from the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[optical fiber to the instrument. A variety of adapters are available
for this
purpose.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Absolute Level
Accuracy]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[The instrument's absolute level is calibrated with a 9.5 μm single-mode
optical
fiber.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The level accuracy when other optical fibers are used is not
guaranteed.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Multimode (GI) fiber provides a relatively accurate spectrum if the
light source is
low-]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[coherent light such as white light, natural light, or an LED. If the
light source has high
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[coherency as in the case of a laser beam, interference will occur
inside the optical fiber,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[and the intensity distribution of light radiating from the fiber tip
will vary according to the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[fiber form. As a result, the spectrum (measurement level) may fluctuate
if the fiber is
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[moved.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[When an optical fiber with a large core diameter or large NA value is
used, a low fraction
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[of the light emitted from the optical fiber is received. Therefore, the
measurement level is
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[lower than the true value, but the optical spectrum is accurate in
relative terms.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Level Accuracy below the Cutoff Wavelength (Short Wavelength) of a
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

**[Connected Optical
Fiber]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[With wavelengths at or below the cutoff level of the connected fiber,
light propagates
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[through the optical fiber in multiple modes. When high-coherent light
from a light source
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[such as a gas laser or DFB-LD light source propagates in multiple
modes, speckle noise
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[contained in the optical fiber output light may become unstable by the
optical fiber's form,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[resulting in an inaccurate measurement
level.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[In such cases, improving the coupling between the light source and the
optical fiber will
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[lessen the level
inaccuracy.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Measurement Sensitivity and Vertical Axis Effective
Range]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[When the measurement sensitivity is set to NORMAL HOLD, the internal
amplifier has
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[a fixed gain. Five different gains are set automatically according to
the reference (REF)
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[level setting. However, the effective range of measurement data is
limited to the following
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[range, using the reference (REF) level (dBm) as a reference.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[REF-20 dBm \< (effective range) \< REF+10
dBm]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[If the level scale is set to 10 dB/DIV, the display would exceed the
effective range, so the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[areas at 10 dB from the screen stop and 20 dB from the bottom are
inaccurate.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[When measurement sensitivity is set to NORMAL HOLD, we recommend
setting the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[level scale to 5 dB/DIV or less.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Under the measurement sensitivity settings NORMAL AUTO, MID, and HIGH 1
to 3,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[an automatic gain is used, permitting measurements over a wide level
range through a
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[single sweep. Select the appropriate sensitivity level based on the
light reception level
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[required for the particular measurement
application.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Ripples in the 1350 to 1450 nm
Area]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Water (OH-) ions present in the monochromator absorb light in the 1350
to 1450 nm
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[area, resulting in ripples in the measurement waveform. Either set a
coarser resolution or
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[use the monochromator in a lower-humidity environment to reduce the
amount of ripples.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Waveforms with Resolutions of 0.020
nm]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[When the resolution is set to 0.020 nm for measurements of a light
source such as a
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[DFB laser in which with the spectral width is narrower than the
instrument's resolution,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[very small spikes may occur at the skirts of the waveform. This type of
spike occurs due
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[to characteristics of the optical block and is not an indication of any
problem. Even if such
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[spikes occur, satisfactory performance in terms of resolution, dynamic
range, and the like
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[can be ensured. These spikes will disappear if the resolution is set to
a coarser value.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Second-Order Diffracted
Light]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[The monochromator in this instrument uses a diffraction grating, and
when light in a
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[certain wavelength range is input, a "grating ghost" of second-order
diffracted light
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[appears.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Therefore, it is important to understand this distinctive
characteristic in order to correctly
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[analyze the measured results from the instrument.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The graph below shows the correlation between the wavelength displayed
on screen and
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[the actual wavelength.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The displayed wavelength is on the horizontal axis, with the true
wavelength on the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[vertical axis. The solid lines in the graph indicate correspondences
between displayed
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[and actual wavelengths. The thick solid line is the correlation with
the correct light
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[spectrum (of course, the displayed wavelength and actual wavelength
match), and
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[the thin solid line shows the correlation with the ghost spectrum of
the second-order
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[diffracted light.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[For example, if 633 nm light is input, a horizontal line is drawn at
633 nm on the vertical
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[axis, and the point of intersection on the graph of the line is the
displayed wavelength.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[From this, you can see that besides 633 nm, a grating ghost appears at
1266 nm.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Explanation]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#ffffff"}**

**[Wavelength Display
Mode]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[• Displays the measured waveform with the wavelength on the X axis.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• The measurement scale and display scale are set based on the
wavelength.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• The X axis unit for marker values and analysis function results is
wavelength.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Frequency Display
Mode]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[• Displays the measured waveform with the frequency on the X
axis.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• The measurement scale and display scale are set based on the
frequency.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• The X axis unit for marker values and analysis function results is
frequency.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Display Units of the X-Axis and Marker
Values]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[The display unit for the marker value (wavelength or frequency) can be
set independently
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[of the waveform display's horizontal axis units (wavelength or
frequency) that were
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[specified using the HORIZON SCALE nm/THz soft key under SETUP.
(Default:
nm)]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[(This key can be used to enter settings such as frequency display mode
on the X axis
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[and wavelength display mode for the marker
value.)]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Also, the MARKER UNIT nm THz soft key's setting changes in conjunction
with the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[setting of the HORIZON SCALE soft key. However, changing the MARKER
UNIT nm THz
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[soft key's setting does not change the setting for the HORIZON SCALE
nm/THz soft key.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Note]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:12.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[The MARKER UNIT nm THz soft key's setting changes in conjunction with
the setting of the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[HORZN SCALE soft key. However, changing the MARKER UNIT nm THz soft
key's setting
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[does not change the setting for the HORIZON SCALE nm/THz soft
key.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[LOG SCALE
\*\*.\*dB/D]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[This key switches the vertical axis to LOG display and sets the level
scale.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The setting range is 0.1 to 10.0 dB/DIV. Settings can be adjusted in
steps of 0.1 dB.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[If you press the COARSE key you can change the numerical value in 1-2-5
steps, for
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[example: 1dB/DIV -\> 2dB/DIV -\> 5dB/DIV.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[When the setting is changed, the displayed waveform is redrawn
according to the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[changed scale.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[If the value is set to a scale larger than 5 dB/DIV in range fixing
mode
(SENS:NORMAL/]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[HOLD) or pulse light measurement mode, the waveform will not be
correctly measured in
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[the vertical direction so a warning is displayed.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Measurement Sensitivity and Vertical Axis Effective
Range]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[When the measurement sensitivity is set to NORMAL HOLD, the internal
amplifier has
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[a fixed gain. Five different gains are set automatically according to
the reference (REF)
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[level setting. However, the effective range of measurement data is
limited to the following
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[range, using the reference (REF) level (dBm) as a reference.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[REF-20 dBm \< (effective range) \< REF+10
dBm]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[If the level scale is set to 10 dB/DIV, the display would exceed the
effective range, so the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[areas at 10 dB from the screen stop and 20 dB from the bottom are
inaccurate.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[When measurement sensitivity is set to NORMAL HOLD, we recommend
setting the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[level scale to 5 dB/DIV or less.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Under the measurement sensitivity settings NORMAL AUTO, MID, and HIGH 1
to 3,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[an automatic gain is used, permitting measurements over a wide level
range through a
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[single sweep. Select the appropriate sensitivity level based on the

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[required for the particular measurement
application.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Log Scale (REF
LEVEL)]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[The setting range for the log scale reference level is -90.0 to 30.0
dBm. Settings can be
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[adjusted in steps of 0.1. The value changes in steps of 1 if you press
the COARSE key.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Linear Scale (REF
LEVEL)]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[The setting range for the linear scale reference level is 1.00 pW to
1000 mW.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[When 1.00 to 9.99 (pW, nW, μW, mW), can be set in steps of 0.01.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[When 10.0 to 99.9 (pW, nW, μW, mW), can be set in steps of 0.1.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[When 100 to 999 (pW, nW, μW, mW), can be set in steps of 1.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[If you press the COARSE key you can change the setting in 1-2-5
steps,]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[for example: 1pW -\> 2pW -\> 5pW -\> 10pW -\> 20pW.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[If you make a change such as changing 999 to 1.00 or 1.00 to 999, the
instrument will be
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[changed.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[(Example: Changing pW to nW or changing nW to
pW)]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[One-Action
Keys]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[This is the general name for a key that uses data from the active trace
waveform (the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[currently displayed waveform) to set measurement conditions.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Setting conditions requires that a waveform is displayed for the active
trace.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[PEAK → REF
LEVEL]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Sets the peak level of the waveform of the active trace to the
reference level.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Displays the specified reference level (peak level value) and waveform
in the reference
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[level setting screen. The reference level setting can be changed after
being set initially.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The setting can be changed within the range of -90.0 to +30.0 dBm for
LOG scale, or
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[1.00 pW to 1000 mW for linear scale. If the peak level value exceeds
the allowed range,
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[it is set to the nearest value in the range and a warning is displayed.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[MARKER → REF
LEVEL]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[This key is used to set the moving marker level as the reference level.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Displays the specified reference level and waveform in the reference
level setting screen.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The reference level setting can be changed after being set initially.
The setting can be
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[changed within the range of -90.0 to +30.0 dBm for LOG scale, or 1.00
pW to 1000 mW
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[for linear scale.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[If the moving marker value exceeds the allowed range, it is set to the
nearest value in the
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[range and a warning is displayed. In the following states, the MARKER →
REF LEVEL
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[key is disabled.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• When the moving marker is
OFF]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[• When both split screens are on
HOLD]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Active trace refers to a target trace to which settings and changes can
be
applied.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[A trace shows a waveform and measurement conditions. The instrument has
a total of
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[seven independent traces (A through G). You can specify Show/Hide on
each trace, and
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[display multiple traces in the waveform screen.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The following explains the soft keys related to trace settings.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[ACTIVE
TRACE...ABCDEFG]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Selects the active trace from among traces A to G.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[You can also switch the active trace using the mouse by clicking TRACE
display A
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[through G on the
screen.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Displaying
Traces]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Selects whether or not to display the active trace on screen.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[VIEW @...DISP /
BLANK]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

["VIEW @ DISP": Displays the waveform on the screen. The trace display
changes to
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[\"DSP\".
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

["VIEW @ BLANK": Does not display the waveform on the screen. The trace
display
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[changes to \"BLK\".
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[When you press this key, the highlight toggles between "VIEW @ DISP"
and "VIEW @
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[BLANK".]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Note that if BLANK is set, markers applied to the trace set in DISP
will be
cleared.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The \"at\" (@) symbol indicates the currently selected trace. One is
included from A to G.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

Mode]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

**[WRITE
@]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[This key is used to set the active trace to write
mode.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[When a trace is set to write mode, waveform data are written to it and

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[measurement. In addition, the trace display on the side of the data

]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[\"WRITE\".]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The \"at\" (@) symbol indicates the currently selected trace. One is
included from A to G.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Fix
mode]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

**[FIX
@]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:10.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[This key is used to set the active trace to data fixing
mode.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[When a trace is set to this mode, its waveform data do not change even
when
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[measurement is performed. Therefore, the waveform on the screen is not
overwritten.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The trace display changes to
\"FIX\".]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[When the FIX soft key is pressed during sweeping, the waveform
displayed at that time
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[is fixed.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[The \"at\" (@) symbol indicates the currently selected trace. One is
included from A to G.
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

**[Gate Sampling
Measurement]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:11.0pt;color:#231f20"}**

[Gate sampling can be used to measure data only when the gate signal is
active during
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[sweeping. By applying an external signal (gate signal) synchronized to
the pulse light
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[emission to the AQ6370D, you can efficiently measure pulse
light.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Because the gate signal and the sampling time are asynchronous, not all
light pulses
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[may be sampled when a single sweep is
performed.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[When the AQ6370D measures several times in repeat sweep mode using the
MAX
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[HOLD function, all the light pulses can be sampled, enabling the full
waveform can be
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[displayed.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:9.0pt;color:#231f20"}

[Because the AQ6370D does not show data that is sampled when the gate
signal
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#000000"}

[is inactive, the wavelength data during this period may be missed, but
because
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#000000"}

[the sampling time and gate signal (pulse light) are asynchronous,
performing
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#000000"}

[repeat sweep using the MAX HOLD function eventually results in all the
waveform
]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#000000"}

[data in the span range to be
shown.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#000000"}

[\* For details on the MAX HOLD function, see section
6.3.]{style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;font-size:8.0pt;color:#000000"}
